pages.name: Qualifying Questions

elements.name: Unsafe
elements.title: Is someone making you or your family feel unsafe?
elements.description: Unsafe could be either physical and non-physical behaviour. For example, stalking or verbal harassment could make you or your family feel unsafe.

elements.name: ExplanationFamilyViolence
elements.title:
The term for the things a family member does to make you feel unsafe is called Family Violence.

Family violence includes many things such as:
  • physical abuse (or attempted abuse),
  • denying food or other basic needs,
  • emotional or mental abuse (stalking, threats, intimidation or harassment),
  • sexual abuse (or attempted abuse),
  • children being exposed to family violence
Click here for more information for what counts as Family Violence.

elements.name: UnsafePartner
elements.title: Is (or was) this person your partner?
elements.description: A partner is someone you are (or were) married to, someone you live (or lived) with in a marriage-like relationship, or someone you have a child with.

elements.name: ExplanationUnsafeNonPartner
elements.title:
For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. This service can only be used to apply for a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order against someone who is (or was) your partner.

If a family member who is not your partner is making you feel unsafe, you can still apply for Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order. Click here for Provincial Court Family Forms.

If someone who is not a family member is making you feel unsafe, you can still apply for an order to protect you. This order is called a Peace Bond. This service cannot be used to get a Peace Bond. If you think you need a Peace Bond, contact the police or RCMP for assistance.

For additional support, call VictimLink BC 1-800-563-0808 (no charge), 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

elements.name: EitherHaveChildren
elements.title: Do either of you have children?

elements.name: ChildrenHaveOtherGuardians
elements.title: Do any of these children have parents or legal guardians other than the two of you?

elements.name: ExplanationChildrenHaveOtherGuardians
elements.title:
For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. This service is currently limited to supporting two partners with children and these children do not have any other parents or guardians.

If any children have parents or guardians other than the two partners, you can still apply for Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order. Click here for Provincial Court Family Forms.

For additional support, call VictimLink BC 1-800-563-0808 (no charge), 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

elements.name: UnsafePartnerMultiple
elements.title: Is there more than one partner making you feel unsafe?
elements.description: There could be more one person making you feel unsafe.

elements.name: ExplanationUnsafePartnerMultiple
elements.title:
You will still be able to use this service but it currently can only accommodate 1 partner making you feel unsafe at a time. You can include an any number of children but only 1 main person applying.

You can use this service more than once for each of the partner making you feel unsafe.

elements.name: OutsideOfBCPOR
elements.title: Does the Protection Order need to be in place outside of BC?
elements.description: A Protection Order usually lasts for one year unless the judge orders a different end date.

elements.name: ExplanationOutsideOfBCPOR
elements.title:
Depending on the place, a Provincial Court Familiy Law Protection Order may not be valid outside of British Columbia.

Consider a Peace Bond or a Supreme Court Family Law Protection Order. This service cannot help you apply for either of these at this time. Consider legal advice for looking into the place where the family member making you feel unsafe is located.

elements.name: PORorPeaceBond
elements.title:
You appear to meet the requirements to apply for a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order.

You may also want to consider applying for a Peace Bond, which is another kind of Protection Order.

Confirm which type of Protection Order you want.
elements.description: describe similarities, where do I start?   (under the button for FLA POR: The family law protection order is a civil order made in family court. It is a criminal offense for the person named in the order to disobey (“breach”) it. If they do so, the police can enforce the order under the Criminal Code and the individual may face significant consequences.)

elements.name: ExistingPOR
elements.title: Do you already have a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order and you need to change it or add more time?

elements.name: ExplanationExistingPOR
elements.title: If you already have a FLA Protection Order, do a Form 2. You can copy most of the content from the original Form 1 or Form 3.

pages.title: Before we begin...
pages.description: There is more than one kind of order that can protect you and your family. This service is for applying for a protection order under the Family Law Act. The following questions will help you decide if the Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order is right for you.
